The army of Gaul was drawn up in two lines, according to the usual praefice of war5 but their experienced leader, perceiving that the numbers of the Italians far exceeded his own, suddenly changed his disposition, and reducing the second, extended the front of his first, line to a just proportion with that of the enemy. Such evolutions, which only veteran troops can execute without con- fusion in a moment of danger, commonly prove decifive: but as this engagement began towards the close of the day, and was con- tested with great obstinacy during the whole night, there was less room for the conduct of the generals than for the courage of the sol- diers.
